channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Merkel Defies Conservative Critics of Her Refugee Policy
item.description: In a speech, she promised the number of refugees would drop, but also spoke against those who “try to whip up sentiment against strangers.”
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and VICTOR HOMOLA

item.title: As Poland Lurches to Right, Many in Europe Look On in Alarm
item.description: Changes under the newly empowered Law and Justice Party are unsettling what had been a model for the struggling post-Soviet states of Eastern Europe.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN and JOANNA BERENDT
item.media:description: Jaroslaw Kaczynski, leader of the governing Law and Justice party in Poland, at a rally in Warsaw on Sunday.

item.title: Egypt’s Inquiry Into Plane Crash Finds No Evidence of Terrorism
item.description: The Egyptian announcement placed the country directly at odds with Russian and Western allies, which have said terrorism was the most likely cause.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Debris from the Russian passenger jet that crashed on the Sinai Peninsula in Egypt in November.

item.title: Defense Chief Heads to Middle East as U.S. Evaluates ISIS Strategy
item.description: The trip by Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter is intended to take stock of recent moves to speed up the military campaign against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Palestinian Rams Car Into Crowd of Israelis at Jerusalem Bus Stop
item.description: About a dozen people were injured and the attacker, a 21-year-old resident of East Jerusalem, was fatally shot before he exited his vehicle, the police said.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN

item.title: As Poland Lurches to Right, Many in Europe Look On in Alarm
item.description: Changes under the newly empowered Law and Justice Party are unsettling what had been a model for the struggling post-Soviet states of Eastern Europe.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN and JOANNA BERENDT
item.media:description: Jaroslaw Kaczynski, leader of the governing Law and Justice party in Poland, at a rally in Warsaw on Sunday.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Depressed Vote Shows Problems of French Banlieues
item.description: Turnout is low because the children of immigrants haven’t picked up the habit of voting and many people feel neglected, the mayor of one Paris suburb said.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN
item.media:description: Residents of St.-Denis, near Paris, in November. According to the mayor of St.-Denis, many of the city’s 110,000 inhabitants are immigrants who cannot vote, and, more significant, their French-born children never picked up the habit.

item.title: French Teacher Lied About ISIS Stabbing, Prosecutors Say
item.description: The authorities said the teacher was being questioned after he claimed to have been attacked at the Jean Perrin preschool in Aubervilliers, a northern suburb of Paris.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:description: French police officers outside a preschool in the Paris suburb of Aubervilliers, where a teacher said he had been stabbed by a supporter of the Islamic State on Monday.

item.title: Bus Crash in Argentina Kills Over 40 Police Officers
item.description: The bus was on its way to San Salvador de Jujuy, a city about 175 miles from the border with Bolivia, when it veered off a bridge and plunged into a ditch.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: Islamic State Gains Strength in Yemen, Challenging Al Qaeda
item.description: An affiliate has taken root in the chaos of a civil war, apparently determined to distinguish itself as Yemen’s most disruptive and brutal force.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA, KAREEM FAHIM and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: The site of a car bombing in Aden, Yemen, this month that killed the provincial governor. The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the blast.

item.title: Gush Etzion Junction Journal: West Bank Shopping Complex, a Symbol of Coexistence, Is Shaken
item.description: Jewish settler leaders have promoted a shopping district as evidence that Israelis and Palestinians can share territory, though a recent spate of violence has rocked the area.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier at Gush Etzion Junction West Bank. The Israeli-occupied area is home to Palestinians and Jewish settlers. It was largely peaceful until about 10 recent attacks in the vicinity by Palestinians.

item.title: Teacher in France Says He Was Stabbed by Man Invoking ISIS
item.description: The authorities said the 45-year-old victim, who was wounded, had described the assailant as invoking the extremist group during the assault with scissors and a box cutter at a preschool.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:description: French police officers outside a preschool in the Paris suburb of Aubervilliers, where a man stabbed a teacher on Monday.

item.title: Thai Man May Go to Prison for Insulting King’s Dog
item.description: The arrest of a factory worker illustrates a feverish campaign to protect the monarchy and rebuff critics of Thailand’s military rulers.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Chaiwat Sardyaem/Bangkok Post, via Agence France-Presse
item.media:description: King Bhumibol Adulyadej of Thailand and the dog he rescued from an alley, Tongdaeng, at a boat race in 2008.

item.title: Sinosphere: China’s Case Against a Civil Rights Lawyer, in Seven Social Media Posts
item.description: The posts by Pu Zhiqiang form the basis of the prosecution’s charges of “inciting ethnic hatred” and “picking quarrels and provoking trouble.”
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER
item.media:description: The lawyer Pu Zhiqiang speaking to reporters outside the Chongqing Higher People's Court on Dec. 28 2012.

item.title: Jacob Zuma Appoints Third Finance Minister of South Africa in a Week
item.description: The president removed David van Rooyen just days after appointing him, then named former finance minister Pravin Gordhan to the post.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: David van Rooyen, left, was sworn in as finance minister by President Jacob G. Zuma in Pretoria, on Thursday. On Sunday, he was dismissed.

item.title: Beijing Court Urges Life Term for Gu Kailai, Wife of Fallen Official
item.description: A Beijing court said her suspended death sentence for the murder of a business associate should be commuted to life in prison, the state news media reported.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Journalists watching a video in 2013 of Gu Kailai, who had been convicted of murdering a business associate. Her husband was the ousted Politburo Standing Committee member Bo Xilai.

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: William Lindesay on ‘The Great Wall in 50 Objects’
item.description: In an interview, the China expert describes his deep affection for the Great Wall of China and how he came to write his fifth book on the subject.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON
item.media:description: William Lindesay's latest book on the Great Wall explores what is arguably China's most celebrated landmark through the weapons, maps, ceramics and other objects that played a role in its history.

item.title: Supporters Rally at Trial for Pu Zhiqiang, Chinese Rights Lawyer
item.description: The trial is the latest attempt by the Communist Party to silence political dissent and rein in activist lawyers who question official policy.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Supporters of the human rights lawyer Pu Zhiqiang demonstrating near the Second Intermediate People’s Court of Beijing on Monday.

item.title: Leaders Move to Convert Paris Climate Pledges Into Action
item.description: Much of the burden for maintaining the momentum of Paris now shifts back to individual countries, and concrete steps for delivering on their pledges.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN and MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Coal vendors in Lucknow, India, earlier this month. The country is struggling to lift more than half of its population of 1.25 billion out of poverty and to provide basic electricity to 300 million of them.

item.title: Climate Deal Is Signal to Industry: The Era of Carbon Reduction Is Here
item.description: The world economy has a long way to go to break away from the use of coal and oil that fueled progress since the Industrial Revolution.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: CLIFFORD KRAUSS and KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: A coal yard worker in Afghanistan. The climate accord signed in Paris encourages businesses to reduce their reliance on coal.
